headline: Obama under fire for slow response to Russian meddling
subHeadline: Does the former president owe the nation an explanation for his silence? Reaction and analysis on 'The Five'

That's the question many are asking about President Obama after "The Five"'s bombshell report last night about how back in October, Mr. Obama said it was basically impossible to rig the presidential election. President Trump today invited Republican senators to the White House and remains determined as ever to make ObamaCare a thing of the past.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: We have really no choice but to solve this situation. ObamaCare is a total disaster. We're going to see what we can do, we are getting very close. But for the country, we have to have health care, and it can't be ObamaCare which is melting down. The other side is saying all sorts of things before they even knew what the bill was. This will be great if we get it done. We have a chance to do something very, very important for the public. Very, very important for the people of our country that we love. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb14', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb14', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: As for the Democrats, they sent some blood in the water.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No surprise that Senate Republicans needed another week or two to try to jam their Trumpcare bill through given everything it would mean.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The Republicans cannot exercise the rotten core at the center of their health care bill. No matter how the bill changes around the edges, it is fundamentally flawed.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This Republican repeal bill is not some fine wine that gets better with age. It turns sour.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But Speaker of the House Paul Ryan is countering by saying that the Democrats don't have any ideas of their own when it comes to improving health care in America. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: PAUL RYAN, SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE
utterances.sentences: Well, I think the left is out of gas. I think they just basically decided to resist, resist, resist. They want government run health care. Government run health care is classing while we speak. It's not working, and so what are we doing? We are replacing with a law that would actually work.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, Greg, you have Paul Ryan saying like, trying to explain it. President Trump trying to explain it, and then that montage of Democrats or same people are going to die.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, this is the way it goes. Democratic Party is the boy who cries murder. You know, everything we do, everything we do is going to cause murder. All they are trying to do is, what's your problem, let me finish -- you're trying to reform. It's something simple. You are trying to reform an entitlement, and that becomes literally a massacre. See you can't even touch anything. I mean, Schumer a.k.a. clown face, says that it's rotten at the core. What is at the core of this bill? Choice. So here's the difficulty we have to understand. We are comparing something mandatory, ObamaCare, to something that is optional, which is this new thing. It's like comparing a prison cell to a bedroom. One is mandatory, one you can leave. You can leave your bedroom, you can't leave a prison cell, you can leave the new bill, you can't leave ObamaCare. So instead of treating these options as the same, because you can't compare a prison cell to a bedroom, why don't you make the cell more like a bedroom and introduce competition and choice. Because it's not going to go away. That's what they are trying to do. They are trying to at the core put choice so that the prison cell is more like your bedroom. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Did you just say make like a bedroom, more competition and choice?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's what you heard.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But you know, that's not a bad idea, Kimberly. Go to my website.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jesse, one of the complains from the conservatives is that it actually does a repeal and replace ObamaCare? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think we are going to find out. But I would rather delay a good bill than rush a bad bill. And McConnell, he is like the Jedi knight of the Senate. So, whatever is going to happen it's going to be a lot smoother than what happened in the House, I can guarantee you that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Wow!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know there's a few Republican senators -- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

And then there is the conservative holdouts that want a full on repeal and replace. And then there were about the deficit and liberty. And then there are some people that are on the fence that love the Medicaid goodies.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, I don't know how they're going to thread the needle. Some people say that McConnell has designed this thing to allow these holdouts to swoop in at the last minute --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh -- with these people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I believe her name was Dana Perino. Swoop in at the last minute with a few tweaks and then claim victory. And if that happens, that's fantastic. But, you know, I just think ultimately the Republicans really want to reduce premiums and reduce the deficit, and they are treating Americans like adults. They're not going to try to force someone to buy a product that they don't like or want or need.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I am all for tweaking. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Kimberly, I did talk to somebody who knows Senator McConnell well, and they said that they believe he would not have postponed this vote if he didn't think that there would be a different outcome and a month then he would have had today.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, I think that's 100 percent correct than you did in your great matter. Great prediction. Now, journal last night think it was going to happen before the Fourth of July's August 1st. I think that they feel very confident that they're going to be able to get this done. They need a little bit more time. It was really quite a big push before the Fourth of July, but the sad part is that the Democrats who voted for Hillary Clinton election, they really think that these Republicans want -- and members of Congress, are going to kill 100,000 people, everybody is going to die. It's murder and mayhem. Just to give one percent of the wealthiest people in America a bit of a tax break. That just makes absolutely no sense. If they think that, then they deserve ObamaCare, not the extraordinary Trump care --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That is what the Democrats are saying. In addition to that, they've taken it a step further. Elizabeth Warren, the senator from Massachusetts today saying that Democrats should run on a single-payer platform. Basically on socialized medicine. What do you think of that?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: So, I have a couple of few things.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I figured you did.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I will get to the bipartisan point first. Social Security is the third rail of American politics. I will now change that and say that health care is the third rail of American politics. And here's why. Because there is no perfect solution. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You're right.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: And I think what the President tried to do with the help of one Republican who voted for the bill, and ten months of hearings, President Obama that is, if he tried to find a way to make the system work. Right? But what you are asking insurance companies to do who are privately owned, for-profit companies, is ensure people they don't want to ensure. Which is a problem with both the Affordable Care Act as well as Trumpcare, whatever, the accessible health space care act, whatever they want to call it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Space.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Because they put (INAUDIBLE) even those one word.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: So, what you have there if you've noticed in this bill, there's a bailout for insurance companies, meaning that they are saying that the insurance market is unprofitable, which leaves to where Elizabeth Warren is going. The only step next is single payer whether you like it or not. Now. Now --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But are they unprofitable because there's not enough competition - - if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: No. I think they're unprofitable because the Affordable Care Act, part of the protection part of it where they have ten things that you have to cover, insurance companies don't want to cover them. Right? And it's beyond just maternity care. But they don't want to cover your ambulance ride if you have a heart attack at your retirement party. Right? So, that's why --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: They could do that before ObamaCare, and ObamaCare point aloud and said, they have to cover for your ambulatory care and your ambulance transfer to the airport. But beyond that point, it doesn't matter what Democrats do. Because you don't need us to pass this bill. Donald Trump's problem is not the Democratic Party. It's not Elizabeth Warren, it's not Bernie Sanders but his problem is his nine Republican senators, it's probably ten by tomorrow, who want to vote against it. That's the problem. Don't blame Democrats. Don't blame the other party.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That is a fair point.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: You guys have a super majority, you can get this deal done in reconciliation. Too bad. Your members won't vote for --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: But who do you blame for the 44 percent of counties that have no insurance providers this year or the other 41 percent that only have one provider and no choice?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Well, I won't tell you -- no, I don't blame ObamaCare. I blame the fact that Donald Trump is campaigned on repeal and replace, the Wall Street is saying that this is going away. So, insurance camps are like, hey, we're not going --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Insurance camp is revealing last year, long before anybody knew he was going to be president --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right. Marco Rubio said, oh, no, no, no.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: But we needed to fix it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Obviously, we can't be able to solve it in this block but we had a good discussion, and obviously more to come. More chaos at CNN over the network's coverage of the Russia investigation. We've got that story, up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Fake news. President Trump loves to call CNN's coverage of the Russia investigation, quote, "fake news." And the network hasn't done anything recently to change his mind. Yesterday CNN announced three of its journalists resigned over a now retracted article that said Trump ally Anthony Scaramucci was under Senate investigation over ties to a Russian investment fund. The network said that the article, quote, "Did not meet CNN's editorial standards." And there's more. Today, the conserved investigative group Project Veritas released an undercover video of a senior producer at CNN criticizing his employer's coverage of the Russia probe.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Honestly, he paints the whole Russia (bleep) --

utterances.speaker: JOHN BONIFIELD, CNN SUPERVISING PRODUCER
utterances.sentences: It's just like mostly (bleep) right now. Like we don't have any -- any giant proof. They really don't have it, but they want to keep digging.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Uh-hm.

utterances.speaker: BONIFIELD
utterances.sentences: And so, I think the President is probably like to say, like, look, you are witch-hunting, like you have no smoking gun. There's no real proof. The CEO of CNN said in our entire meeting, he said good job covering the climate accords. But we are done with that. Let's get back to Russia.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Let's get back to Russia. Well, CNN put out a statement saying it still quote, stands by medical producer John Bonifield and values a diversity of opinion among its staff. Now by that, do they mean a diversity of truth?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There's no such thing as a diversity of truth, Kimberly. I was wondering why they kept doing the stupid story. You know, it's like CNN, the Russia story, it's like a kid staring at a pot of water on the stove having no idea that the burner is off. It's not getting any hotter. But now I know why. It's because they had to keep matching the narrative. They created a story to match the narrative for the purposes of ratings. They were treating the story like professional wrestling. They had villains and heroes and they were following a path towards a climax, except that the climax never comes. That's why they keep rolling the stuff out. And keep going on and on and on. I'll tell you what. We do fixate on stories at FOX, but it's not for ratings. It's because we give a damn. I mean, we talked about Benghazi every single day and it wasn't for ratings, that's for sure. But it's because we cared. And this is why your camera persona, on this table, and your beliefs in the green room should be the same. Because sooner or later you're going to get found out. If you are off there talking about how many guns you own, and then you come on here and start talking about how gun-control needs to be enhanced --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yep.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- you are going to be exposed for that. And that's important.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yep.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: All right. So, Dana, this was a big story that's developing over the weekend, it has continued through this week. And it should, because it matters in terms of journalistic integrity. It seems that CNN was chasing ratings at the expense of human collateral damage and individuals they smeared like Anthony Scaramucci and also a bloodlust to go after the American president and delegitimize them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: A bloodlust? I don't know if I would go that far. I do think that CNN and all -- look, all cable news has a way of obsessing on stories. Remember when they covered the plane, the missing plane for like, I don't know, however long that was? And I assume that they are doing that for business reasons, which I don't know if that is actually working for them, but also because there was this preconceived idea. And what he says in the video is that what he thought was more important was climate change, OK. So there is also another -- they were having an internal fight over what was more important. And you could imagine there's plenty of people in the newsroom which all thought climate change was a lot more important, and the head guys were like, actually, it's not rating it all. Let's go back to the thing that was rating. I can understand that. On the Anthony Scaramucci thing, and I sent you a note about this, he was so classy and gracious when CNN apologized and he was like that's good, we can move on. Then the reporters actually get fired and I'm interested to find out their side of the story. You know one of them, Eric Lichtblau, he's a very formidable adversary as a reporter when it comes to covering the government. He was the one that broke the news about KSM being held and George W. Bush had to come out with that and the "New York Times" ran that even though we asked them not to. But I think that they are trying to cover stories too quickly and to meet a preconceived notion and there's no need to. There's plenty of time. There's plenty of viewers, but to go with a one source story when you have four reporters on it, that seems to me to be way out of bounds.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes, without any evidence whatsoever to support it, Jesse. No facts.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No. I think Dana makes a great point. Russia is CNN's missing plane story and they are not going to find evidence like they did with the plane too. I also think the scandal here is that the medical producer is eating Chick-fil-a. I mean, what kind of medical producer eats Chick-fil-a? I don't get that either. I think the video is a big black eye for CNN no matter how hard they try to spin it. But the core of the video is what everybody already knew, that CNN is biased against Trump, wants him to leave office, and they are pushing at the Russia story for ratings and cash. Now, if a Fox News producer was caught in a video sting saying that the company wants Obama impeached and they're pushing a bogus story about the president's birth certificate just for ratings, and the CEO is on board with it that would be national news. It would be national news. But this was buried just like everything else. But I think the actual real scandal is these three guys resigning, which I think they did honorably for pushing a fake news story --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And also, the birth certificate is real.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure that's the best comparison to -- I think it's probably more of a --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, because this apps (ph) comparison so far --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: -- forced out, paid out, resign from the situation. All right, so what do you think, and I guess you're happy that you work here.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I am happy that I work here. But no, I did get it. We got to split up the two stories, right. So I think the first story was Scaramucci -- journalists get it wrong sometimes. These guys got it wrong. It's unfortunate. They resigned. CNN apologized, let's move on.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: But it wasn't that innocent. This was very specific and --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: No, whatever you want -- which is why I think they resigned.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I would give you one anonymous source.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I will give you all of that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: One anonymous source.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I will give you -- I'm giving you all of that --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: From someone's office.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: but let's --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Give me more Richard.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Not so fast. Let's talk about the second one. So you have a medical producer who doesn't work in breaking news, he doesn't work on any of the major shows. He probably produced for like Sanjay Gupta or somebody or some obscure doctor in the back and they talk about heart disease and eating Chick-fil-a.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Don't you dare (Inaudible) with Sanjay.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: And this is what I call Project Veritas is the epitome of gotcha journalism. They show up. They put the camera in their hats --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Like "60 Minutes."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And you know what? They got him. You know what? They got him.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: But that's my point, like, why can't we just -- I don't understand why, like you should never, ever, ever uphold this type of journalism amongst the real journalists an people who --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wait a second, "60 Minutes" or ABC do sting videos all the time, Richard --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: But also, Project Veritas has been known to doctor videos. They've been known to doctor tapes. They have a horrible reputation. Horrible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Everybody edits down large versions of raw footage.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Pull the facts, they cut, edit, tape.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: So far there's no --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Everybody edits tapes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I'm not saying that they --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: No, no, but so far on this one, as the story stands tonight at this hour, there hasn't been anybody saying to contradict or say this is edited or doctored, et cetera. So, whether you object to the means of collection and the way they do investigative journalism does not change the content of the tape. That's the problem.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: My favorite sting video, if you love someone, set them free.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I've tried that with you so many times.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: More massive problems in Seattle after yet another far left proposal goes awry. Greg analyzes the situation after this quick break. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Tell them to quiet down. A few years ago, Seattle raised its minimum wage to $15 an hour. Liberals applauded, as trained, but some of us wise ones knew better:

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Minimum wage is designed for entry-level -- teens, people who just start in the workforce. It was never originally meant for heads of household supporting families, which may be there, and it maybe a tiny percentage, but this is basically for people who want to move up. If you raise that rung, then you have to raise all the other rungs. That causes more pain for the small businesses because he has to raise everybody's salary. The end result is you take a pie that used to have eight slices and now you've made it six slices. You've eliminated two jobs, which is why pizza joints are closing in Washington.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Good-looking guy and smart. For as predicted the wage hike killed over 6,300 jobs and slashed wages by $125 per month in 2016 in Washington. That's from a new study by the National Bureau of Economic Research. It's real. What The Washington Post calls "bad news for liberals," not workers, but liberals. That's their first instinct, to worry about liberals. They're such jerks. But anybody outside The Post could've seen this coming. Let's say a shop has eight jobs at $7.50 an hour and you double the salaries. If the budget remains constant, you've got to cut four workers. That's math. The media and Dems, they know math but they pretend not to:

utterances.speaker: SENATE MINORITY LEADER CHUCK SCHUMER, D-N.Y.
utterances.sentences: One constant in the last 10 years have been the Republicans in Congress who are standing in the way of raising the minimum wage.

utterances.speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS, I-VT.
utterances.sentences: We have got to raise the minimum wage to a living wage. If you work 40 hours a week or 50 hours a week, you should not be living in poverty.

utterances.speaker: HOUSE MINORITY LEADER NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF.
utterances.sentences: I'm very honored to join the fight for 15. This is a living wage. We're proud of what we've done in California. I know that the distinguished Senator Murray is proud of Washington State, but we want that to happen in the whole country.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Their combined age is 800.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So, they accept long-term hardship in return for immediate, feel good sentiment to be part of the compassionate club even if the club hurts others. The result: They shrink the job pool and future opportunities -- after all these jobs aren't for persons to stay put, but to give them a head start. When I was young, I knew that first crappy paycheck was temporary. Hell, my job title was "temp." But somehow the Dems believe the first rung is also the last rung and then you're the bad guy for saying no. But we know that you can't get to the second rung without a first. And making that rung -- first rung too expensive only means more automation. See McDonald's. Remember the sign, no shoes, no shirt, no service. With automation, it's no salary, no benefits, no humans. You know, I wish -- Kimberly, I hate having to point out that I was right. I would rather be wrong.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: You're brilliant still.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I wish you could pay more at entry-level positions and have more jobs but math says no.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: It sounds wonderful and we want people to do well. We want families to be able to feed their children and to pay for education and for people to be able to leave something to their loved ones so they've been able to live the American dream in this country. It's really what we all want. But what is the best vehicle by which to achieve that? Is it by making this mandatory minimum wage and raising it? Well, no. The economics don't prove true. The math doesn't want (ph) that supports that kind of theory and in fact this is really, in my opinion I think it operates as like an unfunded mandate on small businesses. A mandate, do not work, it only hurts job creation and tells businesses that want to be entrepreneurs and small businesses, hey, sorry, unless you can do this and subsidize the United States economy, you can't live your American dream.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. You know, Richard, I think that thing that people forget about is if you raise the minimum wage in a business that matches say somebody on the upper level, then you got to give everybody else a raise because you can't have like a 16-year-old making $15 when the 60-year-old managers making $15. Do you follow me?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I follow, but I don't agree with your mathematics on that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. You don't have to. It could be wrong.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I know I don't. I know I don't. No, here are my thoughts on this. Don't get me wrong, I think that there -- we've got to do some tinkering with this, right. But I think here's what we know to be true. Most of the people who are minimum wage who are the head of household which is quite a number of --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Small, small number.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: That's a lot like --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, it's part of the whole group.

utterances.speaker: FORWLER
utterances.sentences: All right. And what we know is this, and so when you're taking care of your family, that extra money always goes right back into the economy. So usually what you see when you raise minimum wage like when George Bush did -- he was the last president to raise the minimum wage -- you see an uptick in economic growth because they have less disposable -- they spent all the money they get as soon as they get it because they have to make ends meet. And so we have to create a system where that is not the case and I don't think the business model of not raising the minimum wage works on this one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I would say that the federal minimum wage is what they were talking about there, and it was minimal, but there's not that many people that work in the federal government for minimum wage. Also, the other thing I would say is that an editorial, "The Washington Post" talks about that there was bad news for liberals and you mentioned workers, but they also don't say is that news for the employers because they actually showed in the study that there was an economic impact for those employers. So basically, you have to make a decision on whether you're going to close your business or not.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think Democrats always get burned by their own good intentions. You know, when you raise minimum wage, you make poor people poor. You pull out of Iraq, you create ISIS. You enact Obamacare you raise premiums. You open the borders, it makes people less safe, and you expand welfare it destroys the family and it makes people more dependent.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: This is getting depressing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Democrats always throw more money at things as the solution, but what happens is more money, more problems. Don't forget who said that. I saw one of this -- I don't know. Also, either the Democrats don't understand basic mathematics. Capitalism is not a charity case. Capitalism exists to provide goods and services to people, and make profits for businesses.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Right to free market.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Minimum wage is a stepping stone. You want to be able to first flip burgers and then flip houses. It's not the en result.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. And on that great know, up next, Bernie Sanders is reportedly lawyering up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Getting a lawyer.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Getting a lawyer. Thank you. FBI comes, details.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Next.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: A federal investigation is swirling around Bernie Sanders. According to reports, the FBI is coming looking into whether his wife committed bank fraud when she secured a $10 million loan for the now defunct Burlington College where she previously served as president. One allegation is that Senator Sanders office pressured the bank to approve the loan, although his spokesperson tells Fox that the senator is not personally under investigation. Here's what happened when one of our reporters asked him about it yesterday.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Where are you from?

utterances.speaker: KARA ROWLAND, FOX NEW REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Fox News. CBS is reporting on this, Politico is reporting on this. Do you still believe it's politically motivated, sir?

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Well I'm glad that you're interested in the fact, that the Republican leadership is proposing legislation which would throw millions people off of health insurance.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Greg, your thoughts.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: My thoughts are he really is an expert in student debt. He borrowed millions and closed the college. That's kind of impressive.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And he wants to make sure -- and he wants to make college free.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, he did. Their college is --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, congratulations to Kara Rowland who's our reporter there on the ground. We got that because it wasn't asked of Bernie Sanders over the weekend when a prominent journalist had him on the show. I would say that the problem with Democrats --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Who's mature --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The Democrats --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I could swear you said Chuck Todd.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Come on, let Dana talk.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- think they are above the law. Hillary Clinton thought she was above the law. Bernie Sanders thinks he's above the law on these things. Maybe he's not personally involved but, I mean, you can't d this kind of things and then have your congressional office twist arms.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Jesse, I'm waiting. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I say innocent until proven guilty.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Wow!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He's guilty.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The Sanders could be the new left-wing Bonnie and Clyde if they do get convicted. And if they are convicted, I think President Trump should pardon Bernie, because I think that's the righteous thing to do.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Just when I thought you were going to take the moral high road. Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, everybody deserves their day in court, so we're going to wait to see the full investigation --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Easy to prove this, Kimberly?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: -- no one is retracting the story. Pardon?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Is it easy to prove this?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: It's not that easy to prove. I think it's going to take time. They're going to have to go through and see what kind of specific intent this is going to be, but there is a number of people they have to talk to, to say, you know, what happened, what transpired? Was there any communication, was there any text messages, e-mails, phone calls, personal notes, recollections. Comey type of memos, typed up and leaked to a professor and given to the --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm just shocked the media's not covering the story more. I mean, this is just --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: In all fairness to the media, it was covered by another network today, an hour before the show started.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Once.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: The one that's still in business or not?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The greediest people are socialist.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Can I just say the point of this is just allegation and investigation, and he lawyered up and that is the story, but guess what, Jared Kushner lawyered up, Donald Trump lawyered up, Donald Trump's lawyer lawyered up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That doesn't stop the media for becoming hysterical over just an allegation.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Everybody in the Trump's administration has lawyered up including the vice president. "One More Thing" is up next. Don't go anywhere.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's time now for "One More Thing." I'll go first. Donald Trump has to rename crying Chuck, dancing chuck after new video released of the minority leader cutting a rug at a picnic. There he goes doing his thing.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Hey.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: He can dance well.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I actually think it's not bad.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It looks like a wedding.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I like to see him dancing --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He's got good old man dance moves.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Why is everybody wearing hats?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: A barbecue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm tired of watching it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But I think it's pretty good.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It was a hat party in Brooklyn, OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK, Greg doesn't like my "One More Thing." Kimberly?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I liked it very much.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: OK, fantastic. All right, so everybody, our colleague and friend Eric Bolling has a brand new book out. It is called "The Swamp," he talked about it a lot on "The Five" and it is finally here, "Washington's murky pool of corruption and cronyism and how Trump can drain it." He's very excited about this project. He worked on it a long time. And he is in "New York Times" best seller from his first book. So this is all about the deplorables and he has a dedication inside of it that's fantastic for all of you out there that voted and supported the president and think that D.C. is still a problem. This book speaks to you indeed. And you can get it now on Amazon and the president retweeted it already. So there you go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Congratulations Bolling.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Eric Boling. Dana Perino.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK, you know, our colleague Shannon Bream --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: She is co-host of "America's Newsroom." It's not a book, it is a podcast that she had and I was her guest yesterday. Here's a snippet.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: When I was just a baby, my grandfather bought me -- I was the first grandchild on that side so, he bought me a pony. Her name was Sally.

utterances.speaker: SHANNON BREAM, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: I used to have one named Dixie.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, that's cute.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: You know, it's the south, what are you going to do.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jesse can't wait to listen to that on the way home. It's really extra very interesting, "Living the Bream" podcast. What are you (INAUDIBLE)?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Riveting, riveting, someone bought me a pony named Dixie, oh, mine was Daisy, OK. Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I got an article up by foxnews.com/opinion. It's called, "A country who knew too much." It's pretty interesting, but more important, it's time for this, "Greg Slow News Day." I love it. All right, Jake, damn (ph) and dog, show it. There he is. This is in Fort Wayne, Indiana (inaudible) league baseball game.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, he brings the water.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Brings water to this guy, opens it up, he drinks it. Dog likes to perform simple tricks much like me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's your slow news day.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow, riveting. Aren't you going to comment Jesse?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's the point.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You know what my comment is, how did you not have that video, Dana? She's upset she didn't have the video up until.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: So this is an attack on Donald Trump that I think both Democrats and Republicans can agree on. So, over the week, we found Donald Trump -- he pissed off some golfers because he drove on the green, and you're not supposed to drive on the green. But I guess Jesse will --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But if it's your green are you allowed?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: It is his green. It's his New Jersey green. It is at the Trump National Golf Course in Bedminster, New Jersey.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, it's his own course, so he's allowed to drive on the green?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: So you're going to make an excuse for this one too, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because it's his own course. Kimberly, you had something to add?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Control room, can you please run my fantastic award- winning interview with Mr. Bolling that is found from last night?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I'm here with Eric and I want to say congratulations.

utterances.speaker: ERIC BOLLING, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Thank you, KG.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Another must-read fantastic book, "The Swamp."

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Let's have a cocktail and raise a glass and Donald Trump, drain the swamp.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, set your DVR's and never miss an episode of "The Five." "Hannity" is up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
